title: Day 77 – Monticello, UT to Blanding, UT
content:
Cold brew and granola for breakfast while watching First Man on TV. We had a short day ahead so we weren’t in any rush. On her way out of the parking lot Tess took a spill and got a boo boo on her knee.

We headed south on Route 191 and had some pretty decent hills towards the beginning. Tess was a little pissed about the tendency for the shoulder to disappear or get rugged on the incline. 

Eventually, we hit a point after which it was mostly downhill to Blanding. A mile or so out of town was Yak’s Cafe, which didn’t look like much from the outside, but had some delicious food. I got a breakfast burrito filled with egg, cheese, hash browns, a black bean veggie patty, and covered in homemade green chili sauce! At the table next to us there were a couple of old Native American customers that were struggling a bit with their breakfast. The man asked the waitress if she could cut his pancakes because he was paralyzed on his left side. Tess helped out when they accidentally dropped one of their coffee mugs. We felt bad for them.

Tess wanted to go to the Dinosaur Museum, but it looked like it was geared towards kids so we compromised by going to Edge of the Cedars State Park. It houses one the largest collection of American Southwest artifacts. There were a lot of clay pots. Outside there was an ancient Pueblo ruin with a kiva (underground gathering space) that you could go down into. Tess was a little spooked about going into a dark hole, so I led the way. I passed gas in the kiva, which Tess thought might be bad luck.


Down the path was a sculpture that functioned as a calendar; lines of light would illuminate different drawings on the solstices. Tess got some cool photos from inside.

We pedaled away with a theme song I made up for the park stuck in our heads:

Edge of the Cedars,

Edge of the Cedars, 

Edge of the Cedars,

Yeah

Our destination was Blue Mountain RV Park and Trading Post where we had camping reservations. It was a pretty nice campground with nice bathrooms, though there were sprinklers running for a long time over an area that was mostly dirt, which always makes us a little miffed (especially in the desert). We took a little afternoon nap in the shade.

My chain was squeaking loudly and was in dire need of lube, so I oiled it up. I also had to investigate a slow leak in my tube that had developed. After much searching I found a tiny sharp piece of metal lodged in the tire. I patched the tube and Buddy was back in working order.

After Blanding we had a stretch of 125 miles without services, and just one water source in that stretch, so we had to go to the grocery store to stock up. We left with a ton of goodies that weighed quite a bit. With the the food and water weight, we were going to have a sizably larger load the next day.

We had a salad with chips and guacamole for dinner, popped a gummy, and got to bed. It felt good to have everything prepped for the desert stretch.
